stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the final level's 'retro section,' a large-scale mashup of all original Mario 64 levels. The stream focused on level layout, dealing with technical memory constraints, discussing community feedback on controversial content, and detailing his defiant philosophy regarding potential Nintendo takedowns.

development_findings.summary: The game's final level contains a 'retro section' that is a large-scale mashup of elements from all 15 original Super Mario 64 courses.
development_findings.quote: The retro section is not just level lava then, it's going to be every Mario 64 level at the same time.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively fixing and improving the original Mario 64 assets, such as UV maps, rather than simply reusing them, to create a better aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I'm trying to make it slightly better than vanilla like i have look at this i have to path uv maps like i think we're allowed to fix the uv mapping right.

development_findings.summary: The project is constrained by the N64's memory limitations, forcing Kaze to be selective about level detail and asset usage to prevent overflow.
development_findings.quote: Our main issue here is that we are running out of memory. So we have to keep this somewhat low detail.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle is that the game should be completable without using the new, extended moveset, making advanced abilities optional for skips and speedruns rather than required.
development_findings.quote: I kind of want this game to be beatable without Mario's extended moveset.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for level skips is that they should reward player creativity and not simply trivialize the challenge.
development_findings.quote: I want player to at least be creative when they skip something, otherwise it's not fun.

development_findings.summary: Kaze was inspired by games like 'Only Up 64' and the 'Champions world' from Mario Odyssey/Galaxy for the design of the retro section.
Kaze engaged in a live, collaborative design session with a chat member named 'decar,' immediately implementing their suggestions to fragment the level layout for increased difficulty.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a defiant stance towards potential Nintendo takedowns, viewing it as a 'win-win' situation that would either allow him to release his mod or pivot to a commercial indie game for PR.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed that Nintendo has taken down over 70 of his videos in the past, though it has not happened in the last 4-5 years.
context_findings.quote: You do realise Nintendo took down over 70 of my videos, like I'm very clearly on Nintendo's radar.

context_findings.summary: After receiving community feedback that a level was offensive, Kaze decided to alter it, believing that the audience's perception is what matters, regardless of the creator's intent.
context_findings.quote: If we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad obviously.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's work schedule is directly impacted by his personal life, as he announced a 10-day break from streaming due to his parents visiting and his daughter's baptism.
Kaze believes there is a personal conflict between him and the developer of the Parallel Launcher emulator, leading to targeted patches that prevent his hacks from running.
context_findings.quote: I think the dev of parallel launcher himself like just hates me or something because every time i make a hack he patches parallel launcher so it can't run the hack anymore.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is simultaneously working on a paid commission, a GTA-style parody game called 'Drug Mario,' which involves selling drugs and killing people.

biobak.summary: Biobak created most of the levels for Kaze's separate paid commission project, 'Drug Mario'.
Kaze addressed Biobak (as 'mayamek') regarding a level with controversial content, affirming his belief that Biobak did not create it with offensive intent.
biobak.quote: I didn't think you meant this to be offensive you don't strike me as an edgelord.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned that he and Zeina are hate-watching an anime together, offering a small insight into their shared personal time and media tastes.
zeina.quote: Me and Zeina are currently watching the anime Seven Deadly Sins, we're like hate watching it because it's so goddamn awful.

key_stories.title: The 'All Koopas Are Bastards' Incident
key_stories.summary: The team faced community feedback that a politically-themed level was unintentionally offensive. Kaze addressed the issue live, deciding to alter the level's assets to change its message from a real-world parallel to an in-universe protest against the game's villain.
key_stories.challenge: A level containing 'All Koopas Are Bastards' text and flags resembling pride flags was perceived by some community members as offensive to the LGBT community.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledged the feedback on stream, discussed the difference between creator intent and audience perception, and proposed replacing the controversial assets with Bowser-themed ones.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to alter the level to remove the potentially offensive elements, reframing its message as an in-universe 'anti-Bowser protest' to resolve the community's concerns.
key_stories.key_quote: If we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad obviously.

key_stories.title: The Nintendo Contingency Plan
key_stories.summary: Faced with the risk of a Nintendo takedown, Kaze has formulated a contingency plan. Instead of working in fear, he plans to leverage any legal action as publicity, remove all Nintendo assets, and release the project as an original, commercial game.
key_stories.challenge: The project faces the constant, underlying threat of a legal takedown from Nintendo for using its intellectual property.
key_stories.process: Kaze has formulated a clear contingency plan: if a takedown occurs, he will use the publicity, strip all Nintendo code and assets from the project, rebrand it as an original title like 'Return to Dinosaur Island,' and sell it on Steam.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has adopted a defiant 'win-win' philosophy, feeling prepared for any legal action. He is confident he can either release the mod successfully or pivot to a profitable original game.
key_stories.key_quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.
